text: of all the Italian dishes that have
become popular in the States in the last
20 years polenta is the one whose
difficulty is most overrated it's a very
straightforward thing it's cornmeal mush
you don't have to stand there and stir
it you don't have to know anything to
make it it's great it's easy it's a
fantastic base for loads of different
things it's a whole grain here's how you
do it
these start with say a cup of polenta
and not so much water say a cup of that
also do you haven't turned the heat on
yet right what you want to do with this
is make sure you get rid of all the
lumps so you're making kind of a slurry
okay that is it
now you start cooking contrary to
popular opinion you do not have to stand
here and stir it you can watch it or you
can do something constructive like
reading the New York Times
anyway as we were saying you do have to
stir now and then but you don't have to
stir much there is a trick here I'm just
that every time the polenta absorbs the
water that you're adding to it it's
going to look like it's done
because it's going to be thick it's
going to be party that's what you're
making the fact is though the coarse
cornmeal takes a while to taste done it
looks done but if you keep tasting it it
tastes a little bit raw
so we'll get to a place where we've put
in a lot of water maybe four times as
much water as we have cornmeal and we'll
have a thick mixture but it won't quite
taste done and then you have to lower
the heat as much as you can and just
cook it for a little while longer
we're not there yet actually I've taken
